feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 6:23AM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary: Mountain wave activity has resulted in an area of stronger winds in and around the Cut Bank area this morning. Winds have mostly been on the order of 25 to 35 mph, with gusts up to 55 mph, though a few isolated stronger gusts have been observed. Sustained winds up to 35 mph and gusts up to around 55 mph will remain possible through 9 AM.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Glacier, Western Toole, and Central Pondera

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 4:43AM PDT until October 18 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A long period northwesterly swell will result in an increased risk for sneaker waves and rip currents.
* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern Monterey Bay and Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast Counties.
* WHEN...From Friday evening through Saturday evening.
* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers. Swimmers should always swim near a lifeguard.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING THROUGH SATURDAY EVENING

entry.title: Flood Watch issued October 17 at 1:41AM HST until October 17 at 12:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT THROUGH NOON HST FOR KAUAI COUNTY...
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...Niihau and Kauai.
* WHEN...Until noon HST today.
* IMPACTS...Flood prone roads and other low lying areas may be closed due to elevated runoff and overflowing streams. Urban areas may receive more significant flooding and property damage due to rapid runoff.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - An upper level low and low level convergent boundary are producing scattered thunderstorms just northeast of Kauai early this morning. This system will move over Kauai County through the morning hours, producing periods of heavy rainfall that may lead to flooding in some areas.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Niihau; Kauai Southwest; Kauai Mountains; Kauai North; Kauai East; Kauai South

entry.title: Dense Fog Advisory issued October 17 at 4:33AM PDT until October 17 at 10:00AM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Visibility less than one-quarter of a mile in patchy dense fog.
* WHERE...North Bay Interior Valleys.
* WHEN...Until 10 AM PDT this morning.
* IMPACTS...Low visibility could make driving conditions hazardous.
entry.cap:areaDesc: North Bay Interior Valleys

cap:parameter.value: DENSE FOG ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM PDT THIS MORNING

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 4:11AM PDT until October 18 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.
* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South Washington Coast.
* WHEN...For the first Beach Hazards Statement, from noon PDT today through this afternoon. For the second Beach Hazards Statement, from Saturday afternoon through Saturday evening.
* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or drowning.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions in the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the water. Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially watchful of children and pets.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Clatsop County Coast; Tillamook County Coast; Central Coast of Oregon; South Washington Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT NOW IN EFFECT FROM FRIDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH SUNDAY EVENING

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions in the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the water. Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially watchful of children and pets.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 4:48AM MDT by NWS Pocatello ID
entry.summary:
At 448 AM, satellite, webcams, and weather stations were monitoring several localized patches of dense fog from the Snake Plain up toward the Montana border. Particular trouble spots have included Interstate 15 just south of Monida Pass, Interstate 15 just north of Idaho Falls, Highway 20 between Idaho Falls and Idaho National Laboratory, and Highway 26 between Blackfoot and Idaho National Laboratory, where visibilities have ranged from 1 mile to as low as one-tenth of a mile at times. Model guidance suggests these localized pockets of dense fog will continue through 10 AM.
If traveling or commuting in these areas, be prepared to encounter sudden drops in visibility. When driving into fog, slow down and use low beam headlights. As we are just moving into our cold season where fog starts to occur more frequently, keep in mind that some drivers may not be used to dealing with fog. Use extra caution to watch for other vehicles and hazards.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Arco/Mud Lake Desert; Upper Snake River Plain; Lower Snake River Plain; Beaverhead/Lemhi Highlands

cap:parameter.value: LOCALIZED PATCHES OF DENSE FOG OCCURRING THIS MORNING

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 2:20AM PDT until October 18 at 12:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A moderate risk of sneaker waves.
* WHERE...All beaches of Douglas, Coos and Curry Counties.
* WHEN...From this afternoon through Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can run up significantly farther on beaches than normal, including over rocks and jetties. These waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the cold ocean waters, resulting in serious injury or death. Waves may also lift driftwood logs, trapping anyone caught underneath.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The risk of sneaker waves will peak during Friday evening, but seas will continue to build through Saturday morning and linger through the day Saturday. After brief improvement Saturday night, hazardous conditions due to high surf are possible late Sunday into early Monday.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM NOON PDT TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY MORNING

entry.title: Coastal Flood Statement issued October 17 at 4:17AM EDT until October 18 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Key West FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Minor saltwater flooding.
* WHERE...Florida Keys.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Minor saltwater flooding of low elevation streets and lots is likely. Some storm drains will overflow, and some seawalls and docks will be overtopped. Boaters can expect less clearance under fixed bridges. Motorists should remember that persistent puddles around the times of high tide are almost certain to contain a mix of saltwater.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Monroe Upper Keys; Monroe Middle Keys; Monroe Lower Keys

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 3:41AM EDT until October 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents, large breaking waves, and strong longshore currents in the surf zone.
* WHERE...Hatteras Island beaches north of the Cape.
* WHEN...Through this evening.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries. Strong longshore currents will create dangerous swimming conditions.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Higher than normal water levels will persist into the weekend. The most likely time for strong rip currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide, which will occur around 11:30 AM Friday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Hatteras Island

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH THIS EVENING... ...COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY IS CANCELLED

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 16 at 9:13PM EDT until October 18 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Little Pee Dee River At Galivants Ferry affecting Horry and Marion Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Little Pee Dee River at Galivants Ferry.
* WHEN...Until Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Flood waters will begin to affect residential yards in the Fork Retch community upstream of Galivants Ferry near the town of Nichols. Swampland flooding becomes noticeable and natural boat landings will be flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 9.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early tomorrow afternoon and continue falling to 6.7 feet Tuesday evening. - Flood stage is 9.0 feet. - weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Horry, SC; Marion, SC

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL SATURDAY MORNING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 16 at 8:55PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.
.The St Johns River at Astor remains in Moderate Flood Stage due to recent rainfall and downstream impacts from tides and surge. The river is forecast to remain steady or slowly fall within Moderate Flood Stage through this weekend and into early next week. However, tide and wind effects could periodically slow the decline.
For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Friday afternoon at noon EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest to the river on McPherson Lane.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 3.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:30 PM EDT Thursday was 3.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 3.2 feet. - Flood stage is 2.3 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 11:02AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A pair of light disturbances will impact the Interior, bringing light snowfall throughout the evening tonight through the weekend. Accumulations of 1-3 inches of snow are expected through this weekend with higher amounts in higher elevations and areas near Healy.
Due to the colder temperatures setting in, this could bring our first permanent snowpack for some areas. Snowfall is expected to accumulate on roadways, making travel conditions difficult at times.
entry.cap:areaDesc: White Mountains and High Terrain South of the Yukon River; Fortymile Country; Delta Junction; Upper Chena River Valley; Tanana Flats; Eielson AFB and Salcha; Goldstream Valley and Nenana Hills; Chatanika River Valley; Two Rivers; Fairbanks Metro Area; Nenana; Central Interior; Northern Denali Borough; Southern Denali Borough; Eastern Alaska Range North of Trims Camp; Eastern Alaska Range South of Trims Camp

cap:parameter.value: Light Snowfall Tonight Through This Weekend

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued October 15 at 1:03PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
ESFAFC
The Snow Glacier Dammed Lake is releasing. At this time, we do not expect water levels to reach flood stage on the Snow River, but an additional 1 foot rise of water levels is likely through Friday.
As of 12:45PM, the current water level at Cooper Landing is 10.0 feet. Water levels on Kenai Lake and the Upper Kenai River are expected to rise another half foot, cresting on Friday below flood stage.
There is always uncertainty with Glacier Dam Lake releases. Residents living around Kenai Lake should monitor conditions and prepare for rising water levels.
This statement will be updated daily as more information is available.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Skilak Lake; Interior Kenai Peninsula

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 15 at 10:16AM CDT until October 19 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Aberdeen SD
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Dakota...
James River near Stratford affecting Brown and Spink Counties.
.For sites with a river forecast, the forecast includes precipitation through the next 48 hours. Any future precipitation could affect the forecasts.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...James River near Stratford.
* WHEN...Until Sunday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 14.0 feet, Significant amounts of agricultural lands begin flooding.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:45 AM CDT Wednesday the stage was 14.5 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:45 AM CDT Wednesday was 14.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to continue a slow fall below flood stage early Sunday afternoon. - Flood stage is 14.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
